_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: pump, piping, air scrubber, tank, tank control and valves
_prev_prog_2.Description:
The program and review dates apply to the following sub-processes involving HF 70% handling and storage:

a.     500 lb drums received by truck, stored outside and handled by forklift for internal production or for sales.

b.    500 lb drums transferred into blend tank for dilution to HF 49% or to increase strength of a dilute solution of HF to HF 49%. 



Dates of compliance audits and reviews are applicable to all sub-processes. Maintenance and equipment reviews involve the blend tank operation (b).  Forklift training and maintenance applies to (a); forklift maintenance is performed quarterly or as needed.  Forklift training occurs every three years or as otherwise required by law.  Design codes and process controls refer to sub-process (b). Hazards and passive mitigation systems in use apply to all sub-processes, as all production, receipt and storage are contained by dikes.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Cascade Columbia Distribution (CCD) is a wholesale distributor of industrial chemicals. CCD is a member of the National Association of Chemical Distributors and as such is subject the Responsible Distribution Program. This program requires a safety management system and requires safety commitments beyond those required by OSHA, EPA and DOT. CCD senior management is committed to handling all industrial chemicals responsibly and safely.



CCD, receives, stores and processes 70% Hydrofluoric Acid (HF70%), which is the only chemical subject to the RMP standard on site. The accidental release prevention program utilized at CCD consists of elements required by the EPA Risk Management Plan, Level 2 program. HF70% is brought into the facility in 500 lb (55 gallons) drums, by truck only.  Drums are moved by forklift to the storage area, which is an open-air shed. Drums of HF 70% are moved to the production area by forklift, where they are used to make a more dilute form of HF (49% or less) which is subsequently sold in commerce. This is the primary use of the 70% HF. A few drums of  HF 70% are sold occasionally. 



All areas where HF70% is received, stored, or processed are contained by concrete diking designed to contain more than the maximum amount of product that could be spilled. 



Predictive filling is expected to increase from 42,000 lbs to 100,000 lbs of HF 70% within the next five years. 



CCD has had no incidents involving HF 70% in the last 5 years. 



CCD's emergency response program meets the regulatory requirements of the standard, and addresses such things as spill control, worker personal protection, and coordination with public emergency responders. CCD meet up with Sherwood Emergency Management, Sherwood PD, TVF&R HazMat, and Washington County Emergency Management to create the Plum Models in order coordinate emergency plans more effectively using Wind Speed and Isolation Zone information from it. 



CCD works closely with the local response agencies

and has hosted drills for spill response training. Details regarding the Offsite Consequence Analyses are included in this plan.   



CCD takes great pride in its safety, environmental and risk handling systems.  These systems have proven effective in the past and are continually improved upon as new technology and information becomes available.
